p: The antioxidant activities of essential oils isolated from different organs of both Zanthoxylum species were evaluated with the DPPH assay. Trolox, a molecule well-known for its antioxidant properties, was used as a standard. Figure 3 shows the results. The IC 50 values of the essential oils varied by species and organ. For both plants, an increase in essential oil concentration induced a higher antioxidant activity ( p-value <0.05). Moreover, at the same concentration and for the same organ, all essential oils isolated from Z. psammophilum had higher antioxidant activities than essential oils isolated from Z. mezoneurispinosum ( p-value <0.001). For the Z. mezoneurispinosum specie, the essential oil isolated from the roots showed the highest antioxidant activity, with an IC 50 value of 45.8 ± 0.1 µg/mL. The Trolox standard showed an IC 50 value of 28.4 ± 1.1 µg/mL. The essential oils isolated from the trunk bark and leaves had IC 50 values of 58.1 ± 1.2 µg/mL and 71.4 ± 0.5 µg/mL, respectively. The essential oils isolated from Z. psammophilum exhibited higher IC 50 values: 64.5 ± 1.5 µg/mL for the roots, 91.5 ± 1.4 µg/mL for the leaves, and 160.5 ± 2.1 µg/mL for the trunk bark.
